metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State of Bihar & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant appointed by order dated March 21, 1968, by State of Bihar temporarily to act as Director of Public Instruction, Bihar. On date of appointment, appellant was Director of State Institute of Science. Endorsement stated appointment by promotion on temporary basis for period not exceeding six months in anticipation of concurrence of Public Service Commission.

By order dated November 18, 1968, State Government posted appellant as Director of State Institute of Education, stating appellant had been officiating as Director of Public Instruction by virtue of order dated March 21, 1968.
Appellant filed C.W.J.C. No. 153 of 1969 before Patna High Court challenging order dated November 18, 1968 on various grounds, including allegations of mala fides.

Patna High Court by order dated February 17, 1969 dismissed writ petition summarily without issuing notice to State and other respondents. Held: appointment temporary, no concurrence from Public Service Commission, no prima facie mala fides, order conformed to decision of Council of Ministers, no prima facie case for interference.

Appellant filed application (Supreme Court Appeal No. 42 of 1969) for grant of certificate to appeal to Supreme Court under Arts. 132(1) and 133(1). High Court granted certificate dated March 13, 1969 under Art. 133(1), holding valuation fulfilled assuming claim to office for 3 years 3 months emoluments of Rs. 83,000, primarily under clause (b). Rejected under clause (a).
Respondent No. 1 (State of Bihar) filed C.M.P. No. 4499 of 1969 for revocation of certificate granted under Art. 133(1)(b).

Appellant claimed monthly salary Rs. 1950/-, post scale Rs. 1850-100-2250 with annual increment Rs. 100/-. Would have continued 3 years 3 months before superannuation, earning Rs. 83,000/- but for impugned order.
Public Service Commission did not give concurrence to appellant's appointment as Director of Public Instruction.

legal_issues.text: Whether the certificate granted by Patna High Court under Art. 133(1)(b) is valid, particularly the method of valuation based on future emoluments for 3 years 3 months.
Whether High Court ought to have considered grant of certificate under Art. 132(1) and Art. 133(1)(c).
Whether writ petition alleging mala fides should have been dismissed summarily without notice.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court not justified in rejecting writ petition summarily in view of allegations of mala fides; should have issued notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226; precedents like Century Spinning, Exen Industries, Gyan Chand

petitioner_arguments.text: Certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) correctly granted based on valuation of future emoluments Rs. 83,000/- for 3 years 3 months.
High Court failed to consider certificate under Art. 132(1) and Art. 133(1)(c); remand for fresh consideration. Alternatively, hear appeal on merits as records available.

respondent_arguments.text: Certificate invalid as granted only under Art. 133(1)(b) with incorrect valuation method (future emoluments not 'property'); revoke certificate; appeal incompetent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 133(1)(a), (b); Chhitarmal v. Shah Pannalal, Satyanarain Prasad v. State of Bihar

court_reasoning.text: Certificate granted haltingly under Art. 133(1)(b) with doubts; not properly considered; High Court rejected under (a), did not consider Art. 132(1) or 133(1)(c).
Cannot hear merits on incompetent appeal; precedents on summary dismissal apply only to valid appeals.
Remand High Court to reconsider certificate application afresh under Art. 132(1), 133(1)(b) and (c); clearly specify basis in fresh order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follow precedents like Satyanarain Prasad, Shree Krishna Gyanodaya Sugar.

holdings.text: Certificate as granted invalid; appeal incompetent and must be dismissed.
High Court to reconsider afresh application for certificate under Art. 132(1) or Art. 133(1)(b) or (c), no need for (a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Century Spinning and Manufacturing Company Ltd. v. Ulhasnagar Municipal Council
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court discretion under Art. 226; not dismiss limine if prima facie case against unlawful order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Exen Industries v. Chief Controller of Imports and Exports
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court should not dismiss writ in limine if prima facie case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gyan Chand v. State of Haryana
precedents_cited.relevance: Remand where mala fides alleged and writ dismissed limine.
Test for certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) or (b).

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyanarain Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Remand High Court to consider certificate under other clauses if not done.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shree Krishna Gyanodaya Sugar Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Direct High Court to reconsider certificate application afresh.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; certificate for appeal to Supreme Court based on substantial question of law or valuation.

outcome.summary: Appeal held incompetent due to invalid certificate; dismissed but High Court directed to take up appellant's certificate application afresh under Art. 132(1) or Art. 133(1)(b)/(c), and clearly indicate basis.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to Patna High Court for fresh consideration of certificate.

key_quotes.text: "as the High Court has not properly considered the application filed by the appellant... that application will be taken up by the High Court afresh."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directs remand for reconsideration of certificate.

key_quotes.text: "the certificate as granted by the High Court is not a valid certificate and as such the appeal must be held to be incompetent."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "if a party claims to be aggrieved by the unlawful, arbitrary or unjust order of a public body or authority, he is entitled to a hearing of his petition on merits"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle on summary dismissal of writs (from precedent).
